home.title: Cardiac Electrophysiology Simulator
home.subtitle: Explore advanced mathematical models of cardiac electrophysiology in an interactive environment.

single_stimulus.title: Single Stimulus
single_stimulus.desc: Simulates the response of a cardiac cell to a single electrical stimulus.

multiple_stimuli.title: Multiple Stimuli
multiple_stimuli.desc: Observes the cellular response to a series of stimuli with a fixed interval.

s1s2.title: S1-S2 Protocol
s1s2.desc: Standard protocol to investigate cardiac tissue refractoriness and vulnerability.

s1_s2.title: S1-S2 Protocol
s1_s2.desc: Standard protocol to investigate cardiac tissue refractoriness and vulnerability.

restitution_curve.title: Restitution Curve
restitution_curve.desc: Analyzes the relationship between the diastolic interval (DI) and the action potential duration (APD).

fhn.title: FitzHugh-Nagumo
fhn.desc: Simplified model of cardiac excitability in one dimension.

ms_1d.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer 1D
ms_1d.desc: Mitchell-Schaeffer model extended to one spatial dimension.

model_2d.title: 2D Tissue Model
model_2d.desc: Simulates 2D wave propagation using Mitchell-Schaeffer or Minimal Model.

source_sink.title: Source-Sink Mismatch
source_sink.desc: Simulates propagation through a variable gap in an obstacle.

params.cellType_desc: Defines parameter sets to simulate Epicardial, Endocardial, or Myocardial cells.
params.BCL_S1_desc: Time interval between stimuli in the S1 train.
params.BCL_S2_inicial_desc: Initial interval for the S2 stimulus.
params.BCL_S2_final_desc: Final interval for the S2 stimulus.
params.delta_CL_desc: Amount the S1-S2 interval is decreased in each iteration.
params.inicio_desc: Time instant when the first stimulus is applied.
params.duracao_desc: Temporal duration of the stimulus current.
params.amplitude_desc: Intensity of the applied stimulus current.
params.num_estimulos_s1_desc: Number of S1 stimuli applied to stabilize the system before S2.
params.downsamplingFactor_desc: Reduces the number of saved points to optimize chart visualization.
params.tempo_total_desc: Total duration of the simulation in milliseconds.
params.v_inicial_desc: Initial value of the transmembrane potential (v) at the start of the simulation.
params.h_inicial_desc: Initial value of the gate variable (h), representing sodium channel availability.
params.despolarização_desc: Time constant defining the speed of the action potential upstroke (depolarization).
params.repolarização_desc: Time constant defining the speed of return to rest (repolarization).
params.recuperação_desc: Time constant for the h-gate reopening when potential is low (refractory period).
params.inativação_desc: Time constant for the h-gate closing when potential is high.
params.gate_desc: Potential threshold defining the transition between gate opening and closing states.
params.BCL_desc: Basic Cycle Length: The time interval between consecutive stimuli.
params.num_estimulos_desc: Total number of electrical pulses applied during the simulation.
params.duração_desc: Duration time of the applied stimulus current.
params.intervalo_desc: Time interval between consecutive stimuli in the sequence.
params.S1_desc: Basic stimulus (S1) applied in a regular train to condition the tissue.
params.S2_desc: Extra stimulus (S2) applied prematurely after the S1 train.
params.CI1_desc: Initial Cycle Length (interval between stimuli) for the dynamic protocol.
params.CI0_desc: Final (minimum) Cycle Length to be reached.
params.CIinc_desc: Amount the cycle length is decremented at each stage.
params.nbeats_desc: Number of beats applied for each cycle length before accelerating.
params.tau_in_desc: Time constant defining the speed of depolarization (upstroke).
params.tau_out_desc: Time constant defining the speed of repolarization (return to rest).
params.tau_open_desc: Time for the h-gate to reopen (recovery of excitability).
params.tau_close_desc: Time for the h-gate to close (inactivation during plateau).
params.v_gate_desc: Potential threshold that switches the h-gate behavior (open vs close).

modals.ms_desc_base: The Mitchell-Schaeffer model describes action potential propagation using a potential variable (v) and a gate variable (h), simplifying ionic currents.
modals.minimal_desc_base: The Minimal Model is a 4-variable model that accurately reproduces restitution characteristics and spiral wave dynamics of human cardiac tissue.

model_2d.desc: This tool simulates electrical propagation in 2D cardiac tissue using reaction-diffusion mathematical models. It allows investigating phenomena such as spiral wave formation, reentry, and conduction blocks caused by heterogeneities.

steps.1: Configure geometry and tissue properties in the sidebar.
steps.5: Use the player to view the result.
steps.6: Click on the chart to see the action potential at that point.

model_2d.math_intro: The simulation solves the monodomain reaction-diffusion equation, which describes how transmembrane potential propagates through the tissue.
model_2d.eq_diffusion_desc: Where V is potential, D is the conductivity tensor (diffusion), and I_ion represents the ionic currents of the chosen cell model.

minimal.title: Minimal Model
minimal.vars: 4 state variables: u (potential), v, w, s (gates)
minimal.currents: 3 phenomenological currents: J_fi (fast inward), J_so (slow outward), J_si (slow inward)

numerical_details: Rush-Larsen: Used for integration of gate variables (h, v, w, s).

features.fibrosis_desc: Allows defining tissue regions with zero or reduced conductivity, simulating scars or diffuse fibrosis.
features.transmurality_desc: Simulates electrophysiological differences between heart layers (Endocardium, Mid-Myocardium, and Epicardium) by altering local cell parameters.

glossary.sigma: σ_l / σ_t: Longitudinal and Transverse Conductivity (diffusion)
glossary.tau_in_out: τ_in: Depolarization time | τ_out: Repolarization time
glossary.u_levels: u_o / u_u: Resting potential and threshold levels
glossary.tau_constants: τ_v, τ_w, τ_s: Gate time constants

ms.title: Mitchell-Schaeffer
ms.desc: Simulates the basic electrophysiological response of an excitable cell. This phenomenological model captures essential excitability and refractoriness properties using only two variables (potential and h-gate).

minimal.title: Minimal Model
minimal.desc: Simulates a realistic Action Potential for human tissue. The model reproduces the detailed morphology of Epicardial, Endocardial, and Mid-myocardial (M-cells) cells, allowing the study of APD heterogeneity.

ms.desc: Applies a train of 8 consecutive pulses with a fixed interval (Basic Cycle Length). Allows observation of cell adaptation to the imposed rhythm and stability of stimulus capture.

minimal.desc: Subjects the Minimal Model cell to a fixed heart rate. Useful for analyzing inactivation accumulation and Action Potential Duration (APD) rate adaptation in a steady state.

ms.desc: Standard protocol to determine the Effective Refractory Period. A series of basic stimuli (S1) conditions the cell, followed by a premature stimulus (S2) to test excitability at different repolarization phases.

minimal.desc: Investigates vulnerability and the refractory window in human cells. The premature S2 stimulus reveals the recovery dynamics of slow and fast channels in the Minimal Model.

restitution.what_is_desc: The restitution curve describes the relationship between the Action Potential Duration (APD) and the preceding Diastolic Interval (DI). It is crucial for understanding cardiac stability and the mechanism of alternans.
restitution.apd_def: APD (Action Potential Duration): Time the cell remains depolarized.
restitution.di_def: DI (Diastolic Interval): Resting time between the end of an AP and the start of the next.

minimal.title: Minimal Model
minimal.desc: Generates the Electrical Restitution Curve (APD vs DI) using the Minimal Model. Allows analysis of critical slopes that can lead to instabilities such as cardiac alternans and conduction block.
minimal.method: Explicit Euler method with Rush-Larsen integration for gate variables.
minimal.vars: State variables (v, w, s) control the AP shape.
minimal.currents: Simplified currents (J_fi, J_so, J_si) model depolarization and repolarization.
steps: A train of S1 stimuli is applied to stabilize the cell.
A premature S2 stimulus is delivered with variable interval.
The resulting APD and preceding DI are calculated and plotted.

s1s2.title: S1-S2 Protocol
s1s2.desc: Uses the classic S1-S2 method to build the restitution curve point-by-point, varying the premature stimulus coupling interval until loss of capture.
s1s2.eq_h: dh/dt = (1-h)/τ_open (if v < v_gate) or -h/τ_close (if v > v_gate)
steps: 8 S1 stimuli are applied with a fixed cycle length (BCL S1).
An S2 stimulus is applied with an initial interval (BCL S2).
The S2 interval is reduced, and the process is repeated until refractoriness.

mms.title: MMS Model
mms.desc: Uses the Modified Mitchell-Schaeffer model, which includes adjusted cardiac memory dynamics to reproduce more physiological and less abrupt restitution curves.
mms.eq_h: Modified h-gate dynamics for cardiac memory adjustment.
steps: Similar to S1-S2, but using MMS model parameters.
Focuses on capturing the correct slope of the restitution curve.

dynamic.title: Dynamic Protocol
dynamic.desc: Generates the Dynamic Restitution curve through continuous pacing with progressive frequency, simulating stress conditions or increasing tachycardia.
dynamic.eq_h: dh/dt = (1-h)/τ_open (if v < v_gate) or -h/τ_close (if v > v_gate)
steps: Starts with a long, stable Cycle Length (CI).
Reduces the CI by a fixed amount (CI Inc) after a set number of beats (nbeats).
APD and DI are measured for each beat in the quasi-steady state.

fhn.desc: The FitzHugh-Nagumo model is a simplification of the Hodgkin-Huxley model. It reduces the complexity of ionic currents to two main variables: the transmembrane potential (v), responsible for fast excitation, and a recovery variable (w), which mimics slow refractoriness. It is widely used to study the excitable nature of biological tissues.
fhn.reentry: The 'Reentry' initial condition creates a spiral wave simulating an arrhythmia.
fhn.method: The system is solved spatially using the Finite Difference Method and temporally via the Explicit Euler method.

bistable.desc: The Bistable Model describes wave propagation in an excitable medium using cubic nonlinear dynamics. It simplifies ionic currents into a single variable 'v', featuring two stable states (rest and excited) separated by a threshold, capturing the essence of "all-or-none" propagation.
bistable.method: The equation is solved using the Finite Difference Method for the diffusion term (Laplacian) and the Explicit Euler method for time integration.

ms1d.desc: The Mitchell-Schaeffer model is a simplified phenomenological formulation describing cardiac action potential propagation. It uses two state variables: transmembrane potential (v) and a gate variable (h) governing refractoriness (similar to sodium channel inactivation). Despite its simplicity, it reproduces complex properties like the cardiac tissue restitution curve.
ms1d.method: The diffusion equation is solved spatially using the Finite Difference Method. Temporal integration uses the Explicit Euler method, with conditional equations for the 'h' gate dynamics.

source_sink.desc: The Source-Sink Mismatch simulation investigates the safety factor of cardiac propagation. It models the passage of an electrical wave through a narrow isthmus (slit) into an expanded tissue region. If source current is insufficient to charge the sink, block occurs.
source_sink.geometry_desc: The geometry uses insulating barriers to create a variable-width slit, allowing the study of wavefront curvature effects.
numerical_details: Mesh: Regular rectangular grid with step dx.

features.geometry_desc: Defines the passage width (Upper/Lower Gap) and presence of circular obstacles hindering propagation.

glossary.L_dx: L / dx: Tissue size (cm) and spatial step
glossary.sigma: σ_l / σ_t: Longitudinal and transverse conductivity
glossary.obstacle: Obstacle: Radius and central barrier position
glossary.dt_time: dt / Time: Time step and total simulation duration
glossary.ms_taus: τ_in / τ_out: Depolarization and repolarization times
glossary.ms_gates: τ_open / τ_close: Recovery and inactivation times (h-gate)
glossary.minimal_cells: Cell Type: Defines parameters for Epicardium, Endocardium, or M-Cell

steps: Choose the cell model (Mitchell-Schaeffer or Minimal).
Define gap and obstacle geometry in the 'Geometry' tab.
Position the stimulus (green circle) before the gap.
Click 'Simulate' and observe propagation through the isthmus.
Analyze if the wave successfully excites the tissue after expansion (Sink).
